Situation1: The meeting will cover key project updates that won’t be summarized elsewhere.
Expectation2: Educate the public and the community about their cause.
Situation2: A major news network has just called for an immediate on-air comment to counter misinformation in a breaking story.
Story: I stared at my phone, the meeting reminder flashing just as my email pinged with the news producer’s urgent request. My team was gathering in the conference room, ready to discuss project updates that would shape our next quarter—updates I’d miss entirely if I wasn’t there. I knew my colleagues counted on me to contribute, to ask the right questions, to show I was invested. But the news network’s message was clear: misinformation about our cause was spreading fast, and they needed someone now—me—to set the record straight on live TV. My activist friends always said I was the best at explaining our mission, and I felt the weight of their trust. I could almost hear my manager’s voice, reminding me how important this meeting was, while at the same time, I pictured the community relying on me to speak up. My heart pounded as I stood in the hallway, torn between the conference room door and the phone in my hand, knowing I couldn’t be in both places at once.
